questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute pyelonephritis?

options.a: CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice
options.b: Commonly associated with uric acid stones
options.c: Renal scarring is common in untreated cases
options.d: The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.explanation:
899 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Patients with acute pyelonephritis 
are more likely to have struvite stones, not uric acid stones. This is because of infection 
with urea-splitting organisms such as proteus that release ammonia. This makes the urine 
alkaline and promotes the formation of struvite stones. Acute pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidneys. Ascending 
infection in the urinary tract is the most common route. It is more common in young, sexually 
active women. Up to 50% of children with urinary infections have an underlying anatomical 
abnormality (e.g., reflux or obstruction). Clinical features include: • Prodromal symptoms such as headache, lassitude, vomiting • Flank pain, fever, rigor • Pyuria and occasionally hematuria CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice to rule out pyonephrosis. The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent renal scarring. Surgery is 
indicated only if antibiotic therapy fails.

questions.question:
Question 2: A diabetic patient presents with pyrexia and left flank pain. On examination, Murphy's punch 
sign is positive. CECT abdomen done is shown below. What is the most likely causative 
organism for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given history with Murphy's punch sign positive, and streaks of gas on CECT abdomen point 
to a diagnosis of emphysematous pyelonephritis. Escherichia coli is the most common causative 
organism. Emphysematous pyelonephritis is associated with an acute necrotizing infection of the kidney by 
gas-producing organisms that occurs predominantly in diabetic patients. E. coli produces carbon 
dioxide by the fermentation of sugar. Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. It can be associated with tenderness at 
the costovertebral angle known as Murphy's punch sign. CECT abdomen shows an enlarged destructed renal parenchyma with small linear streaks of gas. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with drainage. In patients who fail to respond to 
treatment, nephrectomy is considered. Note: Clostridium species are the most common causative organisms in emphysematous 
cholecystitis. Murphy's punch sign is also seen in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney. The 
below image shows the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and 
the vertebral column. 900 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 890 
Sold by @itachibot A woman is referred to you for evaluation of recurrent episodes of right flank pain and 
high-grade fever. She also had a history of recurrent urinary calculi in the past. CECT 
abdomen done is shown below. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario with CECT abdomen showing bear paw sign is suggestive of 
xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Subcapsular nephrectomy is the preferred treatment 
in patients with XGP. It is a form of chronic pyelonephritis seen most frequently in middle-aged diabetic women and, 
rarely, in children. XGP is most commonly caused by proteus followed by E. coli. The disease is 
usually unilateral and is associated with prolonged obstructing nephrolithiasis. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyxes showing a multiloculated 
appearance. This is referred to as the bear paw sign. Histology shows foamy, lipid-laden 
macrophages.

questions.question:
Question 4: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the 
most likely diagnosis? 891 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal 
tuberculosis. Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during 
the end stage of genitourinary TB. Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the 
bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB. CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT 
urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in 
patients with putty/ cement kidneys. 901 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma 
and tubules.

questions.question:
Question 5: A man presented to the OPD with hematuria and intermittent right flank pain. He received 
ATT for pulmonary TB two years ago. Urine analysis revealed pus cells, and no growth was 
seen on culture. Which of the following lesions are associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given history of pulmonary TB and presence of sterile pyuria on urine culture is suggestive of 
a diagnosis of renal tuberculosis. All of the above lesions can be seen in renal TB. Lesions in the kidney include: • Papillary ulcer - earliest lesion • Pyonephrosis/ Putty kidney - caused by multiple scattered papillary ulcers undergoing caseous 
necrosis, which later become filled with pus • Cement kidney - caused by calcifications in putty kidney • Perinephric abscess - by extension of pyonephrosis or tuberculous renal abscess • Pseudocalculi - occurs when calcium gets deposited in a papillary ulcer healed with fibrosis • Ghost calyces - caused by the destruction of the calyces • Thimble bladder - caused by fibrosis. The earliest sign is the paleness of bladder mucosa. 
managed by ileocystoplasty • Golf hole ureteric orifice - Dilated ureteric orifice. Managed by ureter reimplantation.

questions.question:

conditions?
questions.explanation:
The Bosniak classification system is used for assessing patients with renal cysts. It divides renal cystic masses into five classes based on imaging characteristics seen on CECT. It is 
helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of clinical 902

questions.question:
Question 7: An ultrasound abdomen done for evaluation of flank pain in a man revealed a large mass 
arising from the right kidney. CECT abdomen done showed the presence of a central stellate 
scar. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the presence of a central stellate scar on CECT is suggestive of a diagnosis 
of oncocytoma. Oncocytoma is the most common benign renal tumor. It arises from cells rich in mitochondria. 
Familial type is associated with Birt Hogg Dube syndrome. Most patients remain asymptomatic 
even with large oncocytomas. In some cases, it may present as an abdominal lump. The cystic variant of the tumor is classified as Bosniak class III on CECT. On histological 
examination, large eosinophilic cells owing to an abundance of mitochondria are seen arranged in 
distinct nests. Partial nephrectomy is the preferred treatment. Note: Central stellate scar on CECT is also seen in chromophobe RCC and focal nodular 
hyperplasia of the liver. The given CECT shows an enhancing right renal mass with a central stellate scar 903 
Sold by @itachibot The given slide shows large eosinophilic cells arranged in nests

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presented to the casualty with severe back pain and vomiting. He was diagnosed to 
have tuberous sclerosis during childhood. CT scan revealed the presence of renal tumors with 
high-fat content as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and CT findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of angiomyolipoma. Angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign neoplasm of the kidney. It contains blood vessels, smooth 
muscles, and fat, and arises from perivascular epithelioid cells. It can occur in isolated forms or 
may be associated with tuberous sclerosis. Patients can either be asymptomatic or may present with abdominal pain or a lump. Some 
patients may also present with massive hemorrhage referred to as Wunderlich’s syndrome. Lenk’s 
triad seen in patients with Wunderlich’s syndrome includes: • Abdominal mass 904 
Sold by @itachibot • Abdominal pain • Shock Due to the presence of abundant fat tissue, they can be easily identified on CT scans. 
Immunohistochemistry is positive for HMB 45. Treatment includes: • Asymptomatic tumors and tumors less than 4 cm in size - Observation with serial CECT • Symptomatic tumors and tumors more than 4 cm in size - Partial nephrectomy/ nephron-sparing 
surgery • Bleeding tumors - Angioembolization followed by partial nephrectomy Everolimus is FDA approved for the treatment of AMLs. Note: HMB45 is positive on IHC for malignant melanoma and angiomyolipomas.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is false regarding Grawitz tumor?

options.b: Derived from the proximal tubular epithelium
options.c: Clear cell is the most common histological type

questions.explanation:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) also known as Grawitz tumor or hypernephroma, is a 
radio-resistant tumor. RCC accounts for 85% of renal neoplasms in adults. It is more common in males between 
the sixth to seventh decades. Clear-cell RCC is the most common type of renal cell cancer. The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron is usually the site of origin of RCC. Risk factors for RCC: • Smoking • Obesity • Family history of RCC • Drugs like phenacetin and diuretics • Thorotrast exposure • Increased protein intake

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not true regarding the presentation of renal cell carcinoma?

options.a: Flank pain is the most common presentation
options.b: It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
options.c: It may be associated with pulsatile bony metastasis
options.d: Palpable abdominal mass is part of the classic triad seen in RCC

questions.explanation:
The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria. The classic triad (seen in <10% of cases) includes : • Gross hematuria • Flank pain • Palpable abdominal mass Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the 
left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, 
the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC. 905 
Sold by @itachibot Patients may also present with paraneoplastic syndromes. RCC can give rise to pulsatile bony 
metastases.

questions.question:
Question 11: A man presents with intermittent hematuria and flank pain for 2 months. He is a known 
smoker and is found to be anemic. Further investigations reveal an enhancing lesion arising 
from the right kidney. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is not likely to be 
seen in his condition?
questions.explanation:
Hematuria and flank pain in a known smoker with the given investigation findings is suggestive of 
renal cell carcinoma. Cerebellar degeneration is not a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with 
RCC. Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC include: Endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes - • Stauffer syndrome - non-metastatic liver dysfunction, characterized by elevated serum bilirubin, 
ALP, and prolonged prothrombin time • Hypercalcemia - due to increased vitamin D, PTH-related protein • Hypertension • Polycythemia • Galactorrhea • Cushing’s syndrome • Alterations in glucose metabolism Non-endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes include Lambert Eaton syndrome (neuromyopathy), 
amyloidosis, anemia, vasculopathy, nephropathy, coagulopathy, elevated ESR, prostaglandin 
elevation. Elevated ESR is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC. Note: Cerebellar degeneration is a paraneoplastic syndrome in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.question:
Question 12: Lab values from a routine workup done for a hypertensive man are given below. Further 
investigations revealed hepatosplenomegaly with a 5.5 cm tumor arising from the right 
kidney. No signs of metastasis were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of Stauffer syndrome in a patient with renal cell 
carcinoma. Stauffer syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. It is a non-metastatic liver 
dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6. It is characterized by the presence of hepatosplenomegaly 
with no features of metastasis and the following lab findings: • Hyperbilirubinemia • Raised ALP • Hypoalbuminemia • Hypergammaglobulinemia • Prolonged prothrombin time 906 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to the development of renal failure in patients with 
advanced chronic liver disease. Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction 
(HVOTO).

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma is characterized by multiple losses of 
entire chromosomes?
questions.explanation:
Chromophobe type renal cell carcinomas (RCC) are uniquely associated with multiple losses of 
entire chromosomes, including chromosomes 1, 2, 6, 10, 13, 17, and 21. Thus, they show extreme 
hypodiploidy.

questions.question:
Question 14: A man was referred for the evaluation of an unsteady gait with weakness of his legs for the 
past 1 month. He gave a history of similar problems in his brother. Imaging revealed 
cerebellar hemangioblastomas and bilateral renal masses suggestive of RCC. Which 
histological type of this renal malignancy is he most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar 
hemangioblastoma which along with the family history points to a diagnosis of von Hippel 
Lindau’s disease (VHL). Clear cell RCC is the most common type associated with VHL disease. VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is caused by a germline mutation of 
the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A second hit can increase the predisposition to a variety of 
neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina, and clear cell renal 
carcinoma(in 40-60%). The given slide shows clear cell RCC.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is the most common method of diagnostic investigation in patients 
suspected to have hypernephroma?
questions.explanation:
907 
Sold by @itachibot The most common method of diagnostic investigation in hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma 
is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Characteristic features of RCC on CT scan include: • Enhancement of the lesion after injection of IV contrast • Thickened irregular walls • Thickened or enhanced septa within the mass or multilocular mass CT scan has replaced IVP and ultrasound as the radiological modality of choice to evaluate renal 
masses. MRI can be performed for diagnosing poorly characterized renal masses on CT or if a CT scan is 
contraindicated (in case of allergy to IV contrast). It also helps in defining tumor extension into 
the renal vein or IVC. The below image shows a cystic tumor involving the left kidney suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 16: 895 
Sold by @itachibot A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown 
below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in 
patients with this tumor?
questions.explanation:
The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal 
cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they 
form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries. The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also 
metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain. Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes. The image below shows multiple round opacities in bilateral lungs suggestive of cannonball 
metastasis in the lungs. 908 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor 
less than 4 cm in size?
questions.explanation:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is the treatment of choice for 
tumors <4 cm. Indications for partial nephrectomy: • Tumors < 4cm • Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm • Bilateral tumors • Tumor in solitary kidneys • Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction. Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. Treatment of renal cell carcinoma: RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor. Radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and 
regional lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is no longer removed except in cases of obvious tumor 
involvement. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumors 
and enlarged lymph nodes. Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also 
indicated in advanced/metastatic tumors. Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma. 910

questions.question:
Question 19: You are assisting in a radical nephrectomy in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. Which of 
the following statements is false regarding this procedure?

options.a: Early ligation of vessels is performed to reduce tumor spread
options.b: It includes removal of the kidney with Gerota's fascia
options.c: Excision of ipsilateral adrenal gland is done in all the cases
options.d: Regional lymphadenectomy is done for tumors more than 10 cm in size

questions.explanation:
Excision of the ipsilateral adrenal gland in radical nephrectomy is done only if the tumor is 
adherent to it. Classical radical nephrectomy includes: • Early ligation of the renal artery and vein to prevent tumor spread • Removal of the kidney with primary dissection external to the Gerota's fascia • A complete regional lymphadenectomy from the crus of the diaphragm to the aortic bifurcation Regional lymphadenectomy is not required in every radical nephrectomy. It is indicated in the 
following conditions: • Enlarged lymph nodes on imaging • Cytoreductive surgery for metastatic disease • Tumor size > 10 cm • Nuclear grade  3 • Sarcomatoid histology in renal tumor • Presence of tumor necrosis on imaging • Extrarenal tumor extension • Tumor thrombus • Direct tumoral invasion of adjacent organs

questions.question: Question 20: Which is the most common abdominal tumor seen in children?
questions.explanation:
Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal tumor of childhood. 911 
Sold by @itachibot Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of 
childhood. The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on CT, but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. 
Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral 
calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma. Features

questions.question:
Question 21: A boy was brought by his parents, with complaints of blood in his urine. A left-sided reniform 
mass was palpated. Further investigations were suggestive of Wilms tumor. Which of the 
following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Most cases occur in children between 2-5 years of age
options.b: It is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood
options.c: Early metastasis occurs to the liver
options.d: Nephrogenic rest cells are precursor lesions

questions.explanation:
Metastasis to the lungs occurs early in Wilms tumor. Liver, bone, and brain metastasis is rare. Wilms tumor or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of 
childhood. It is commonly seen in children between 2-5 years of age. More than one-third of the 
cases contain precursor lesions known as nephrogenic rests. Asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally is the most common presentation. 
Patients may also present with: • Abdominal pain • Gross painless hematuria • Fever • Hypertension Most unilateral tumors are treated by chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and 
dactinomycin) followed by nephrectomy. Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done. Partial nephrectomy is considered 
if all the following conditions are met: • The tumor involves only one pole of the kidney • No evidence of collecting system or vascular involvement 912 
Sold by @itachibot • The involved kidney has an appreciable function • There are clear margins between tumor and surrounding structures It is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney. Preoperative chemotherapy 
can be used in these cases to induce tumor shrinkage.

questions.question:
Question 22: 897 
Sold by @itachibot A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had 
a history of hematuria two weeks back which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a 
right-sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What all investigations will you do?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features of a ballotable renal mass with hematuria in a 3-year-old child are suggestive 
of Wilms tumor and FNAC is not done in this condition. Investigations in suspected cases of Wilms tumor: • Laboratory study - shows hematuria, polycythemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated APTT • USG with doppler study of renal veins - for evaluation of the collecting system and to look for 
tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava • CECT abdomen - to identify the extent of the disease, to access the contralateral kidney, and for 
metastasis • MRI - not used routinely as it requires sedation • Positron emission tomography(PET) scan - to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions Diagnosis should be made by imaging studies and it is confirmed after nephrectomy. A biopsy is 
discouraged in this condition as it results in disease upstaging. Only in cases with atypical 
presentation such as older age, signs of infection, etc, or with unusual imaging findings a core 
needle biopsy via the posterior approach can be performed. Note: Neuroblastoma also presents similar to Wilms tumor. It is commonly seen in children of 
preschool age. Affected children commonly present with a palpable abdominal mass and the most 
common site of the tumor is the retroperitoneum. Therefore, this disease becomes an important 
differential diagnosis. So we should also test for the presence of vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) in 
this patient to exclude this tumor.

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following is the most important factor in determining the prognosis of a child 
with Wilms tumor?

options.d: Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.explanation:
The most important prognostic factor in Wilms tumor is the histology of the tumor. Wilms tumor (WT) is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the metanephric blastema, with 
no differentiation into tubules or glomeruli. It usually arises from three tissue elements (triphasic 
tumor): • Blastema (poor prognosis if the blastemal component is more) • Epithelium • Stroma Wilms tumors lacking anaplasia (presence of atypical, polyploid mitotic figures, large nuclear size, 
and hyperchromasia) are designated as having “favorable histology". 913 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following staging systems is used for staging of Wilms tumor in a child posted 
for partial nephrectomy post neoadjuvant chemotherapy?

options.b: International society of paediatric oncology staging
options.c: American joint committee on cancer staging

questions.explanation:
International society of pediatric oncology (SIOP) is the post-chemotherapy staging system used 
for Wilms tumor. The SIOP approach involves the shrinkage of the tumor using preoperative 
chemotherapy. Option A: Children's oncology group (COG) staging is used for post-operative staging followed by 
chemotherapy. It was previously known as national Wilms tumor staging (NWTSG). Option C: TNM staging (AJCC) is used for staging internal malignancies such as gastric, renal, 
breast, etc. Option D: Shimada staging is used for neuroblastoma.
